events.title: Birth of Scott Joplin
events.summary: Scott Joplin was born into a musical family of railway laborers, which influenced his future in music.
events.fun_version: Scott Joplin was born into a musical family of railway laborers, which meant that instead of a lullaby, he was serenaded by the soothing sounds of trains chugging and whistles blowing. Who needs a musical education when you've got a mother who can hit a high C while engineering a railroad?

events.section: Life in the Southern states and Chicago
events.title: Early Musical Career
events.summary: In the late 1880s, Scott Joplin transitioned from a railroad laborer to a traveling musician. He performed at various local events as a teenager and was later part of the Texarkana Minstrels in 1891, participating in efforts to fund a monument to Jefferson Davis. His journey took him to various red-light districts in the mid-South, where he played pre-ragtime 'jig-piano'.
events.fun_version: In the late 1880s, Scott Joplin managed to escape the clutches of a railroad laborer life to become a traveling musician. Imagine a teenager, instead of hauling trains, belting out tunes that made folks tap their feet! He joined the Texarkana Minstrels in 1891, participating in efforts to fund a monument to Jefferson Davis. Scott's journey then took him to red-light districts in the mid-South, where he played pre-ragtime 'jig-piano'!

events.section: Life in the Southern states and Chicago
events.title: Chicago World's Fair
events.summary: During the 1893 Chicago World's Fair, Joplin formed a band, playing cornet and arranging music. Despite the fair's limited showcase of African-American talent, it attracted millions of visitors, significantly impacting American cultural life, including the popularization of ragtime music. Joplin's performances garnered popularity among attendees.
events.fun_version: During the 1893 Chicago World's Fair, Joplin played cornet and arranged music! This fair may have limited the showcase of African-American talent, but it still attracted millions of visitors. Joplin's performances significantly impacted American cultural life and were more refreshing than a cold lemonade on a hot summer day!

events.title: Maple Leaf Rag Published
events.summary: Joplin's composition, 'Maple Leaf Rag', became one of the most influential ragtime pieces, helping him gain fame.
events.fun_version: Joplin's composition, 'Maple Leaf Rag', tickled the piano's funny bones and catapulted him to fame, making him the original ragtime rockstar with a top hat!

events.title: First Opera Scored
events.summary: Joplin scored his first opera, 'A Guest of Honor', but it was confiscated for non-payment of bills and is now considered lost.
events.fun_version: Joplin's first opera, 'A Guest of Honor', was such a hit that it got a one-way ticket to the land of the lost, all because of some unpaid bills!

events.title: Creation of A Guest of Honor
events.summary: During his prolific period, Joplin founded an opera company consisting of 30 members and produced his first opera titled "A Guest of Honor." The national tour experienced numerous challenges, and it remains uncertain how many productions took place, as well as whether it was an all-black or racially mixed show.
events.fun_version: During his prolific period, Joplin decided to gather 30 members and start an opera company. He rolled out his first masterpiece named 'A Guest of Honor'—it sounds fancy. The national tour was fraught with challenges; getting 30 people to agree on what to wear was no small feat. It remains uncertain how many productions took place, and the big question remains: was it an all-black show, or did they mix it up?

events.title: Marriage to Freddie Alexander
events.summary: In June 1904, Joplin married Freddie Alexander, a young woman from Little Rock, Arkansas, to whom he had dedicated his work "The Chrysanthemum." The marriage was short-lived as she tragically passed away on September 10, 1904, from complications related to a cold, just ten weeks after their wedding.
events.fun_version: In June 1904, Joplin married Freddie Alexander, a lovely woman from Little Rock, Arkansas, to whom he dedicated his work “The Chrysanthemum.” Just ten weeks after they said "I do," she tragically passed away from complications related to a cold.

events.title: Move to New York City
events.summary: In 1907, Joplin moved to New York City, seeking a producer for a new opera, but was unsuccessful.
events.fun_version: Joplin moved to New York City in 1907, hoping to get a producer for a new opera. Unfortunately, the only thing he produced was a collection of rejection letters!

events.title: Struggles with Treemonisha
events.summary: In 1911, facing difficulty in finding a publisher for his opera 'Treemonisha', Joplin took the initiative to publish it himself in a piano-vocal format. Despite his hopes, the opera was poorly received when it was presented to a small audience in Harlem in 1915, emphasizing the challenges he faced in his artistic pursuits.
events.fun_version: Joplin decided that finding a publisher for his opera 'Treemonisha' was harder than finding a needle in a haystack, so he published it himself in a piano-vocal format! When he finally unveiled his masterpiece to a small audience in Harlem in 1915, the audience's reaction was more crickets than applause—emphasizing the challenges he faced in his artistic pursuits.

events.title: Self-Publishing 'Magnetic Rag'
events.summary: In 1914, Scott Joplin and his wife Lottie self-published his composition known as 'Magnetic Rag'. This endeavor was part of his efforts to establish a music company named Scott Joplin Music Company, which he had formed the previous December. This was a significant step in promoting his music independently.
events.fun_version: In 1914, Scott Joplin and his wife Lottie decided to self-publish his composition 'Magnetic Rag', likely because he couldn't find anyone who would publish it. This was part of his efforts to establish a music company called Scott Joplin Music Company, which he had formed the previous December. It’s not just a catchy name; it was a desperate attempt to promote his music independently!

events.title: Death of Scott Joplin
events.summary: Scott Joplin passed away after suffering from dementia due to neurosyphilis, marking the end of the ragtime era.
events.fun_version: Scott Joplin passed away after a battle with dementia caused by neurosyphilis. Just like that, the ragtime era went kaput!

events.title: Mental Health Admission
events.summary: On February 2, 1917, Joplin was admitted to the Manhattan State Hospital, which was a mental institution. This step highlighted the severe impact of his health struggles on his mental well-being, particularly due to his ongoing battle with tertiary syphilis.
events.fun_version: On February 2, 1917, Joplin was admitted to the Manhattan State Hospital, a mental institution, as his health had become a bit crowded with issues. His ongoing battle with tertiary syphilis significantly impacted his mental well-being.

works.title: I Am Thinking of My Pickanniny Days
When Your Hair Is Like The Snow
